Did not work for a law enforcement agency before applying, but within 2 years before applying completed police officer entrance-level training that meets or exceeds the requirements under Regulation .09 of this chapter.
The Deputy Director shall review the information contained in the request under §E of this regulation to determine if the:
Individual meets the eligibility requirements under §E of this regulation; and
Police officer entrance-level training that the individual completed meets or exceeds requirements under Regulation .09 of this chapter.
When reviewing the minimum academy hourly requirement, the following information may be considered:
The review will compare the applicant’s approved academy hours with the amount of Maryland academy hours required by regulation at the time of academy attendance.
Topics taught during the applicant’s in-service training may be considered toward the minimum academy hourly requirement. An annual repetitive topical area may only be considered once.
Specialized training received during the applicant’s career that is relevant to the topical areas may be considered toward the minimum academy hourly requirement.
The Deputy Director shall notify the agency head of the decision.
If the Deputy Director grants the waiver, the Deputy Director shall notify the agency head that the individual shall meet the following requirements before certification:
Selection standards under Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
The training requirements under §E(8) of this regulation
If the Deputy Director grants a waiver of full entrance-level training, the individual shall successfully complete the following:
Portions of entrance-level training at a class I or II Commission-certified police academy relating to the:
Maryland Criminal Code,
Maryland Motor Vehicle Code, and
Maryland Juvenile Law and Procedures;
Emergency medical care under Regulation .09 of this chapter;
A Driving Under the Influence Detection and Standardized Field Sobriety Test course approved by the Commission; and
If the law enforcement agency authorizes the individual to carry or use a firearm:
Entrance-level firearms training and qualification for the firearm under COMAR 12.04.02; or

If the Deputy Director determines that the individual previously completed training that is equivalent to the entrance-level firearms training required under COMAR 12.04.02 for the agency-approved firearm, the individual shall be required to complete annual firearms classroom instruction and training and qualification required by COMAR 12.04.02 for the agency-approved firearm.
An agency head may petition the Commission to review a decision by the Deputy Director to deny a waiver of an entrance-level training requirement.
A petition for a waiver on behalf of an individual may not again be submitted under this regulation within two years after the date on which the Commission has:
Denied the petition for the waiver on behalf of the individual; or
Upheld the decision of the Deputy Director to deny the petition for a waiver.
Urine Sample Collection.
A law enforcement agency conducting drug screening shall ensure that the process used by the law enforcement agency includes the minimum requirements under this regulation.
A law enforcement agency conducting drug screening shall:
Verify the identity of the individual providing the sample by examining a driver's license or other acceptable means of photographic identification;
Obtain the urine sample in a manner that reasonably prevents substitution, alteration, or tampering;
Ensure that a minimum of 50 milliliters of urine is collected from the individual providing the sample;
Ensure that:
A urine sample is collected using a proper container that has been sealed by the manufacturer;
Once the seal is broken by the individual supplying the urine sample and the urine sample is deposited in the container, the container is sealed by the individual supplying the urine sample;
The container is sealed using tamper-proof tape that extends over and around the container cover;
Once the container is sealed and accepted from the individual supplying the sample, ensure the sample is labeled with the:
Name of the individual supplying the sample;
Date the sample was given; and
Name of the individual who received the sample;
Ensure that before the individual provides a urine sample, the individual provides written consent for the:
Collection of the sample;
Analysis of the sample; and
Disclosure of the analysis results to the employing law enforcement agency and the Commission; and
Secure, maintain, and transport the sample in a manner that preserves the chain of custody.
Positive Urine Sample Results.
A urine sample screened positive under §C(2) of this regulation is considered evidence of recent use of a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana.

A positive screen for a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana conclusively establishes that the individual providing the sample is not of good moral character established under Regulation .04 or .07 of this chapter and may not be employed or certified by the Commission as a police officer.
The agency head shall ensure that a positive screen for controlled dangerous substances, narcotic drugs, or marijuana was not a result of legal use.
Urine Sample Analysis.

To ensure the reliability and integrity of the testing process, the employing law enforcement agency conducting drug screening shall ensure that the process used by the law enforcement agency to analyze the sample includes the minimum requirements under this section.
A law enforcement agency conducting drug screening and analyzing a urine sample shall:
Conduct urine sample analysis according to provisions under Health-General Article, §17-214, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Ensure that the urine sample is screened by an enzyme immunoassay, radioimmunoassay testing method, or another equally scientifically rigorous screening method; and

At a minimum, ensure that the screening method includes testing for the presence of the controlled dangerous substances, narcotic drugs, or marijuana, or classes of controlled dangerous substances, or their metabolites listed in §C(3) of this regulation.

A positive screen is indicated if the test result meets or exceeds an amount at the following levels measured in nanograms per milliliter specified for each controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana, or classes of controlled dangerous substances, or their metabolites as follows:
Amphetamines — 1,000;
Barbiturates — 300;
Cannabis or cannabinoids — 50;
Opiates — 300;
Cocaine or cocaine metabolite — 300;
Phencyclidine — 25; and
Benzodiazepines — 300.
Confirmation of a Positive Screen Required.

A positive screen of a urine sample for each substance identified under §C(3) of this regulation shall be confirmed using gas chromatography, mass spectrometry, or other equally scientifically rigorous testing method.

A urine sample resulting in a positive screen using the method under §C(2)(b) of this regulation alone is inconclusive, unless the positive screen result is confirmed according to §C(4)(a) of this regulation.

section.heading: Prior Substance Abuse by Applicants for Certification.

para.text: Scope. This regulation applies to an individual on whose behalf an employing agency is applying to the Commission for certification or recertification of the individual as a police officer.
General.

An individual involved in prior or current illegal use, sale, manufacture, or distribution of a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana as the terms are defined under Regulation .01 of this chapter and as specified in this regulation has demonstrated character traits, judgment, behavior, or activity which adversely predict or affect the ability of the individual to perform the duties of a police officer.
A law enforcement agency may set more restrictive standards than those specified in this regulation.

For the purpose of this regulation, marijuana is considered to be separate from a controlled dangerous substance or human-made synthetic cannabinoid or cannabimimetic agent as defined under Regulation .01B of this chapter.
Prohibitions — Initial Certification. An individual is ineligible for initial certification as a police officer in Maryland if the individual has:
Been convicted or otherwise found guilty of selling, manufacturing, or distributing a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana;
Ever illegally sold, produced, cultivated, distributed, or transported a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana;
Illegally used a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug for any purpose within the 36 months before application for certification;
Illegally engaged in the use of marijuana for any purpose within the 12 months preceding the date of application for certification;
Ever illegally used a controlled dangerous substance, or narcotic drug for other than experimentation as specified under §D of this regulation; or
Ever illegally used a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana while employed to enforce federal, State, or local law by any government entity.
Presumption of Experimentation. The illegal use of a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug is not experimentation if the applicant:
Ever used:
Heroin;
Phencyclodine (PCP); or
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD); or
Used a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug, or any combination of controlled dangerous substances or narcotic drugs:
A total of five or more times; or
One time since becoming 21 years old.

Prohibitions — Recertification. If an individual is currently certified, or was previously certified, as a police officer in Maryland the individual is ineligible for recertification if the individual illegally used, ingested, possessed, sold, produced, cultivated, distributed, or transported a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana on or after the date of the individual's initial certification as a police officer in Maryland.
Indication of Use of a Controlled Dangerous Substance, Narcotic Drug, or Marijuana.

If any part of the background investigation indicates an applicant currently or previously used a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana, the law enforcement agency shall investigate to determine if the use falls under the prohibitions specified in this regulation.

The law enforcement agency shall verify the veracity of the applicant's statements, responses to questions, and any other information provided by the applicant related to the use of a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana using a truth verification device.
If the law enforcement agency determines the use is prohibited by this regulation, the applicant is ineligible for certification by the Commission as a police officer.

If the law enforcement agency determines the individual is currently using a controlled dangerous substance, narcotic drug, or marijuana in violation of State or federal law, the individual is ineligible for certification by the Commission as a police officer.

If an individual becomes certified by the Commission as a police officer, the law enforcement agency employing the individual shall document and maintain information used to establish the individual's substance abuse history required by this regulation. These records are subject to audit.
Certification.
The Commission may certify an applicant if the applicant’s last use of marijuana preceded the applicant’s date of application for certification by:
Three or more years; or

Less than three years, but not less than 12 months, on the condition that the applicant agrees to complete an annual substance abuse test during the two years following the applicant’s date of initial certification.
If certification is granted to an applicant who only qualifies under § G(1)(b) of this regulation, the employing agency shall:
Notify the applicant of the additional mandatory substance abuse testing requirement; and
Schedule the conditionally certified officer for an annual substance abuse test at the discretion of the employing agency in accordance with the regulations established in 17.04.09.04.
Petition for Special Consideration.

An agency head submitting an application for certification for an individual with a history of illegal use of a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug may petition the Commission based on articulated unique circumstances of the individual’s use of a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug for a final determination as to the use being experimentation as specified under §D of this regulation.
The agency head, or a designee, submitting a petition under §H(1) of this regulation shall:
Specify the illegal controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug used;
Indicate the number of times the illegal controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug was used;
Provide the individual's age at the time of each use;
Indicate how the information concerning the use of the illegal controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug came to be known by the agency;
Provide information concerning the agency's attempt to verify the information;
Identify the specific factors that the agency head believes the Commission should consider when making a determination as to experimentation that, at a minimum, include information concerning:
Length of time used;
The motivation for the use;
The time that has passed since the last use;
How the illegal controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug was obtained;
How the illegal controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug was ingested;
Why the individual stopped the use;
The individual's ability to perform as a police officer; and
Any other information that supports the unique circumstances that the agency head wants the Commission to consider; and
Submit the petition to the Executive Director of the Police Training and Standards Commission.
The Executive Director shall submit a petition received under §H(2) of this regulation to the Police Training and Standards Commission at the next scheduled meeting following receipt if the petition:
Provides the information required by this regulation; and
Is received at least 30 days before the next scheduled Commission meeting.
Hearing Not Required.

An individual applying for certification has no right to appear before the Police Training and Standards Commission for the purpose of challenging a law enforcement agency’s determination that the individual used a controlled dangerous substance or narcotic drug contrary to the standards established by this regulation.
The Police Training and Standards Commission’s consideration of a petition under §H of this regulation is not a hearing.
Field Training Required; Exceptions.

Except as provided by §A(3) of this regulation, an individual shall successfully complete Commission-approved field training as required under this regulation before receiving police officer certification or recertification under this chapter.
As provided by this regulation, field training shall be successfully completed by an individual for each law enforcement agency employing the individual.

If an individual holds a position listed under Public Safety Article, §3-201(f)(3)(i) or (ii), Annotated Code of Maryland, the individual may be certified or recertified as a police officer under this chapter for the law enforcement agency with which the individual holds the position without meeting the requirements of this regulation.
An individual may receive provisional or temporary certification as a police officer under this chapter without meeting the requirements of this regulation.

When Field Training Is to Be Completed and Minimum Hours for Field Training. The following table provides the minimum hours of field training to be successfully completed and when the field training is permitted to be undertaken by an individual for whom certification as a police officer is requested:

para.text: Field Training Monitoring and Coordination.
A law enforcement agency’s field training shall be coordinated and monitored by:
The law enforcement agency head; or
An employee of the law enforcement agency designated by the law enforcement agency head.

If an employee of the law enforcement agency designated by the law enforcement agency head is responsible for coordinating and monitoring the agency’s field training, the employee is required to have successfully completed:
A Commission-approved supervisor training course under Regulation .13 of this chapter; and
A Commission-approved field training officer course as provided by §E of this regulation.
Field Training Officer Requirements.
A field training officer shall:
Meet the requirements established under this regulation and by the Commission;
Be a police officer for at least 2 years immediately prior to being approved by the Commission to be a field training officer;
Be approved by the Commission as a field training officer;
Except under provisions of §D(4) of this regulation, successfully complete a Commission-approved field training officer course; and

Within every 4 years following initial completion of a field training officer course, successfully complete a minimum of 7 hours of cumulative instruction that have been approved by the Commission to be provided to an individual who has been approved as a field training officer.
To successfully complete an initial field training officer course, an individual shall:
Attend a minimum of 90 percent of the total hours of instruction established for the field training officer course; and
Achieve at least a score of 70 percent on each test given as part of the field training officer course.

The law enforcement agency or academy conducting a field training officer course shall report to the Commission the name of each individual who successfully completes the field training officer course.
The Deputy Director may excuse an individual from completing all or a portion of the minimum requirements for a Commission-approved field training officer course required by this regulation if:

The individual submits to the Deputy Director documentation that the individual has successfully completed training that is the equivalent to all or the portion of the minimum requirements for a Commission-approved field training officer course; and

The Deputy Director finds the documentation provided verifies that the completed training is equivalent to all or the portion of the minimum requirements for a Commission-approved field training officer course.
Field Training Officer Course — Application, Requirements, and Approval.
A field training officer course shall be approved by the Commission, and provided by the law enforcement agency or academy that has received the course approval under this section.
An application for a field training officer course approval shall be submitted to the Commission by a law enforcement agency or academy that requests approval of the course:
At least 20 days before the field training officer course begins; and
In the format required by the Commission.
The application for approval for a field training officer course shall include the:
Number of hours of instruction to be provided by the course;
Names and qualifications of the instructors for the course;
Testing and evaluation methods for an individual enrolled in the field training officer course; and
Other information required by the Commission.
If the Commission approves the field training officer course:
The Commission shall assign the approved field training officer course an identification number; and
Commission approval of the field training officer course is valid for 3 years following the approval date.
Proposed Change to Commission-Approved Field Training Officer Course.

If a law enforcement agency or academy that has received Commission approval for a field training officer course proposes to change the format, an instructor, the content, or the testing or evaluation methods of the course as most recently approved by the Commission, an application for approval of the change shall be submitted to the Commission by the law enforcement agency or academy at least 20 days before the change to the field training officer course is proposed to be implemented.
The proposed change becomes effective when approved by the Commission.
An approved field training officer course shall provide instruction:
Conducted only by individuals who are certified by the Commission under COMAR 12.04.06.08 or who possess an exemption under COMAR 12.04.06.04;
For a minimum of 21 hours; and
On the training objectives required by the Commission for the Commission-approved field training officer course.
For a minimum of 3 years, a law enforcement agency or academy conducting a Commission-approved field training officer course shall maintain the following documentation related to the course:
Rosters of individuals participating in the field training officer course;
The tests, test scores, and evaluations of individuals participating in the field training officer course;
Description of the evaluation process for individuals participating in the field training officer course;
Field training officer course lesson plans; and
Other documentation required by the Commission.
Agency Field Training Policy Required.
A law enforcement agency shall adopt a written policy on the agency’s field training based on a model policy approved by the Commission.
The policy, at a minimum, shall include:
Length of the agency’s field training;
An outline of the training subjects, orientation, and other activities to be provided as part of field training;
Responsibilities of the individual supervising field training;
Selection process for field training officers;
Training of field training officers;
Guidelines for a field training officer’s evaluation of the performance of an individual participating in field training;
Reporting responsibilities of field training officers; and
Guidelines for evaluation of field training officers.
Supervising an Individual During Commission-Approved Field Training.
Except for provisions under §G(2)and (3) of this regulation, during Commission-approved field training, an individual shall be under direct supervision of:
A field training officer from the law enforcement agency employing the individual; or
If a field training officer is not available, a police officer of supervisory rank from the law enforcement agency employing the individual.
Exception to Supervision During Field Training.

For a period that does not exceed 10 percent of the total time of an individual’s field training, the individual may be under the direct supervision of a police officer of the law enforcement agency who is not a field training officer or police officer of supervisory rank.

Under extenuating circumstances when a field training officer or officer of supervisory rank is not available for at least 89 percent of the total time of an individual’s field training, the agency head may request the Deputy Director to approve alternative supervision during the individual’s field training.
The Deputy Director may approve an alternative to the supervision required by this section during Commission-approved field training:
For a limited period of time, as determined by the Deputy Director; and
Under conditions and circumstances specified by the Deputy Director.
During field training, an individual who is engaged in specialized training or orientation duties that do not entail enforcement functions:
May engage in that training or those duties for up to 5 percent of the total time of the individual’s field training; and
While engaged in that training or those duties is not required to be under the direct supervision of a field training officer or police officer of supervisory rank.
If an individual successfully completes the law enforcement agency’s field training, the law enforcement agency head, or the individual designated to supervise field training shall:
Complete and submit a written statement to the Commission indicating that the individual has successfully completed the required Commission-approved field training; and
Sign and date the statement.

Documentation to Be Maintained Related to a Law Enforcement Agency’s Field Training. For a minimum of 3 years, a law enforcement agency shall maintain the following documentation related to the law enforcement agency’s field training:
The agency’s written policy for field training;
Rosters of individuals participating in field training;
The tests, test scores, and evaluations of individuals participating in field training;
Description of the evaluation process for individuals participating in field training;
Field training lesson plans and guides;
An outline of the training for individuals participating in field training;
At least once every 2 weeks during the individual’s field training, summaries of the performance the individual participating in field training;
The field training officer’s final competence report on each individual participating in field training; and
Other documentation required by the Commission.
Audit.
A Commission-approved field training officer course and Commission-approved field training are subject to review and audit by the Commission.

The Commission may suspend or revoke approval of a field training officer course or law enforcement agency’s field training if the Commission determines that the field training officer course or agency field training fails to meet the Commission requirements.

section.heading: Minimum Standards — Police Officer Motorcycle Training.

para.text: A police officer who is authorized by the police officer’s employing law enforcement agency to operate a law enforcement agency motorcycle on January 1, 2014, is not required to complete motorcycle training established under this regulation for as long as the authorization in effect on January 1, 2014, continuously remains in effect.

Except under §A of this regulation, before a police officer is authorized to operate a law enforcement agency motorcycle, the police officer shall successfully complete police officer motorcycle training approved by the Commission.
For police officer motorcycle training to be approved by the Commission, the police officer motorcycle training shall, at a minimum, include the following subjects:
Capabilities of a motorcycle;
Factors contributing to motorcycle accidents;
Accident avoidance maneuvers;
Fundamentals of handling and riding a motorcycle;
Emergency and nonemergency motorcycle operation and handling techniques;
Motorcycle braking techniques;
Impact of adverse weather conditions on operation and handling of a motorcycle;
Daylight and reduced-lighting motorcycle operation and handling;
Operating and handling a motorcycle in confined areas; and
Officer survival related to motorcycle traffic stops and violator contact.
Police officer motorcycle training shall include activities to ensure that the police officer meets performance objectives, approved by the Commission, that are based on:
Evaluations of investigations of law enforcement agency motorcycle accidents that occurred within the previous 5 years; and
Recommendations developed by a Statewide panel.
The Statewide panel under §D of this regulation shall:
Be composed of one supervisory law enforcement agency motorcycle operator from each Maryland law enforcement agency that uses a motorcycle for law enforcement purposes;
Annually designate a chairman from panel membership; and
Make recommendations to the Commission concerning police officer motorcycle operator training.
